page.lettertext:
fol.214r
21 of July
1594
.
Maye it please yo
r
good lordshipe by yo
r
lettere of the 7 w
ch
I Receaved the 19 havinge had full Intellygence that hir
Ma
tie
is determyned to goe forwarde w
th
hir purpose for
the of
Breste
and to have the assystance of the stat
required therunto I moved them in it yesterdaye and had ther
Answeare
tely w
ch
was to this effecte that they have
sygnefyed by their Letteres alredy to hir Ma
tie
that they will
straine ther Abilletyes to the uttermoste degree to seconde
hir dessigne, and when so evere they may knowe hir
finall Resolutyone they will presently Arme their Navie
for theyr thinke it very Necessary that they shold be firyste
mad acquainted w
th
the tyme to sette foarthe the place of
the Rande vous the Nomber of hir Shipes, Souldiores
and Munissyone, pouder and other provissyone w
th
all
the projecte of the service
to
the end they maye
ceed w
th
a sounde delyberac
o
n and provid them selves thearafter
of every thinge Requisite, That other wise yf they shold
presentely sete forwarde it mighte befall them at this
tyme as it wold have done before uppon my firste
proposityon, that in makynge seedely toward
portesmo-
the
and
Plymothe
as Was required then of them
they shold have made a Fruteles voyage, & burdened
the Contrey w
th
a Needles Charge, for two or thre Mo-
nthes, so as Nowe at this presente they shold have wa-
nted the meanes to yelde any Succore, In w
ch
respecte they are desyrous to knowe hir Ma
tie
, hir laste
Determenac
o
n, w
th
every
tyculere & Necessarye
Cercomstance, and that then for their porc
o
n they
will alwayes be
f
as forwarde as Cane in Reason
be Required, If I had knowne thos
tyculer dem-
aund
w
ch
it seemed by yo
r
letteres, hir Ma
tie
po-
sed to their Agente
M
r
Caron
I mighte better have
byne able to Negotyate w
th
them, for Nowe I Cold
but dealle in Certene generall termes, Not knowing
what mattere thes demaund
mighte im
te, Heare
is No Resolutyone taken, for any other imploymente of
their forces at home the state seeming bente to
Refreshe their Souldiores, for a whille in theire
Garrysones townes
in
for w
ch
I wilbe Earneste,
thos of hir Ma
t
to be somwhat better furneshed,
they passed apromys a greate whille whill since
to the
Frenche Kynge
that after
Groeninghen
was
Reduced, they wolde spare him 3000 footemen &
500 horse for the space of
30
three monthes to be
Comaunded by the
Duke of
Bouillon,
and emplo-
yed as he thoughte good againste the Contreys
of
Artoys
and
Henolle
or any other place to the-
anoyance of the Enemye, this promyse being Ma-
de I suppos they will
forme, yf the Duke be
Redy for it, and hathe Caste his plote to good eff-
Effecte.
fol.214v
Effecte, wherunto as it seemethe they attend to knowe
his Answere / The Deputyes for
Scotland
are up
o
their departures whose presente at the Christen-
inge to the Vallue of 1200
li
, and Certene pattente
from the
vinces inclosed also in a Boxe of golde
Contayninge the graunte of an Annualle pensione
of 500
li
duringe the Lyfe of the Younge
prince
to be enjoyed by him selfe or bestowed uppon any other
but this they are unwillinge to have it publyckly
knowne,
Havinge No other mattere I take my
humble Leave From Hage July 21
1594
.
